content: gander copyright © general hogbuffer 2012 gander as in the male goose as the first glimmer of inspiration came from the classic flying geese quilting pattern this is essentially a very simple repeating stranded pattern and your selection of yarns will determine whether you will end up with a jazz age riot of colours or a very understated optical effect as always make sure you have read the whole of the instructions before starting to make sure you are aware of all the options size due to the nature of the repeat in the pattern this design is easiest sized up by adjusting your needle size vs yarn thickness the pattern repeat is only 6 sts but to get the pattern to work after the heel you would need to add or subtract 2 repeats i e 12 sts stranded knitting has a very reduced ability to stretch compared with regular stocking stitch so you will need more stitches than you would use for a plain sock i wear a plain 64 st sock and i need to work a stranded sock with 72 sts feel free to message me on ravelry if you need help with adjust- ing the size properly material sock wool in 4 ply / fingering weight in at least two contrasting colours my sock is worked with 6 colours but you can use as many as you feel like for this reason this would also be an ideal sock to use up leftovers as a guideline you will need around 5 metres of yarn to complete a 10 row line of triangles per colour needle size 2 75 mm or size needed to get the right dimensions see sizing above you will need 2 circulars which i will call needle 1 and needle 2 these are equally easy to work on dpn s though in that case your first and second needle will equal needle1 and your third and fourth will equal needle 2 further requirements tapestry needle stitch markers although you could do it without if they irritate you 2 dpn s will be helpful even if you work on circs but they are not absolutely essential gander page 2 cuff using your favourite cast-on method and colour 1 cast on 72 sts and close to a round taking care not to twist the cast-on work k2 p2 rib for as many rounds as you would like your cuff to be i did 24 rounds for my sam- ple on my sample socks i actually worked the cuff with 80 sts and decreased down to 72 sts in the first plain k round if you have larger calves and/or don t like tight cuffs this may be an option to consider leg join your colour 2 and start working the leg following chart a for the first 5 rounds 12 repeats around the leg 6 repeats per needle after round 5 break colour 1 and introduce colour 3 after round 10 break colour 2
